sentence.content: As the Pentagon launched a barrage of airstrikes into Syria late Monday, Sen. Tim Kaine, D-Virginia, who was an early backer of President Obama&apost;s first presidential campaign and his hand-picked chairman to run the Democratic National Committee, says he is concerned about presidential military action into Syria without congressional authorization.
It was notable that most of the statements of support after the air campaign began came from congressional Republicans.
Both the House and Senate recessed last week so that members could go home to campaign for the midterm elections.
Before Congress left both chambers voted on a narrow measure that gave President Barack Obama the authority to train and arm Syrian rebel groups.

But Republicans and Democrats on Capitol Hill were split on the question about whether the administration had the authority to use an existing authorization to combat al Qaeda as the justification for continuing or expanding an airstrike campaign against ISIS in Iraq and Syria.
The administration argued it didn&apost;t need any new authority, but some members maintained that it was Congress&apost; role, not the President&apost;s, to declare war.
House and Senate leaders said they were open to holding a vote on a new measure giving new parameters for military action against ISIS -- but not until after the election.

The news that five Arab nations joined the United States in the military operation will certainly help reassure those on Capitol Hill who warned against the United States taking the lead on a fight without the support of those in the region.

Most members of Congress expected the airstrikes to occur after they returned home to their districts, and privately many of them conceded that they were relieved not to have to take a vote on a controversial issue just weeks before voters went to the polls in November.
On Monday Obama personally called House Speaker John Boehner and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi to notify them that the military operation inside Syria would begin later in the evening.
Vice President Joe Biden reached out to one of the administration&apost;s most vocal critics, South Carolina Sen. Lindsey Graham.
Graham told CNN&apost;s Dana Bash that Biden told him the airstrikes would be "intense" and a "sustained effort."
Biden also called both the Senate Intelligence Chair Dianne Feinstein, D-California, and the top Republican on the panel, Sen. Saxby Chambliss, R-Georgia.
In a statement Chambliss noted the support of other nations: "I commend our allies in the region for stepping up and demonstrating their commitment to the fight against ISIL.
I&apost;m hopeful these strikes directed at hard targets will result in measurable progress towards degrading ISIL&apost;s capabilities and possibly even taking out ISIL fighters and leadership."
Key cabinet leaders also reached out to top committee leaders.
Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel called House Armed Services Chair Buck McKeon, and National Security Advisor Susan Rice called House Foreign Affairs Chairman Ed Royce.
In a statement late Monday night McKeon said, "This is one step in what will be a long fight against ISIL.
With strong coalition partners, a capable military, and a clear mission; it is a fight we can win."
House Homeland Committee Chairman Michael McCaul released a statement shortly after the news broke, and the Texas Republican pledged his support for the mission.
"To defeat ISIS, we must cut off the head of the snake, which exists in Syria.
I support the administration&apost;s move to conduct airstrikes against ISIS wherever it exists," McCaul said.

But Michigan GOP Rep. Justin Amash, who opposed the legislation giving the administration the authority to send weapons to moderate Syrian groups, ripped congressional leaders for skipping out on a debate on military action.
"It&apost;s irresponsible & immoral that instead of debating & voting on war, congressional leaders chose to recess Congress for nearly two months," Amash said in a tweet on Monday night.
